G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3..proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs, and thus falls within the jurisdiction of the Massachusetts Superior Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2..proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County because the cause of action arose within this county and the Premises where Plaintiff was injured is located at 123 Elm Street, Somerville, MA 02144, in Middlesex County.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant owed a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition for its business invitees, including Plaintiff, and to protect invitees against risks of harm that Defendant knew or reasonably should have known about.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.support_reasoning: This excerpt is from a concurring opinion and does not itself articulate or apply the specific duty alleged (reasonable care owed by a business occupier to invitees regarding known or reasonably knowable risks). Instead, Justice Kaplan critiques the traditional invitee/licensee/trespasser classifications and suggests they should not control the measure of responsibility. While the full Mounsey decision is an important Massachusetts premises‑liability case, this quoted passage does not state or affirm the particular invitee‑duty proposition for which it is cited.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

Wilbur v. Gross, 421 Mass. 718, 721\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or occupier who invites members of the public onto its premises for business purposes owes a duty of reasonable care to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect lawful visitors against foreseeable risks of harm.
Wilbur v. Gross, 421 Mass. 718, 721\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a public school teacher’s First Amendment rights and the limits on school officials’ discretion in disciplining and rehiring an untenured teacher. It does not involve premises liability, duties of owners or occupiers to business invitees, or any discussion of maintaining property in a reasonably safe condition or protecting visitors from foreseeable harm. Accordingly, it does not support the stated proposition about Massachusetts premises liability law.

Polak v. Whitney, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 349,.raw_text: Polak v. Whitney, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 349, 353–54 (1985).
Polak v. Whitney, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 349,.proposition: This duty includes the obligation to use reasonable care to (a) inspect for dangerous conditions; (b) discover and remedy hazards on the premises; and (c) warn invitees of dangers which the owner knows or reasonably should know about and which invitees are unlikely to discover on their own.
Polak v. Whitney, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 349,.support_reasoning: The court expressly states that a landowner owes invitees a duty to exercise reasonable care, including maintaining the premises in a reasonably safe condition and warning guests of unreasonable dangers the owner knows or should know about. While the opinion does not separately spell out a distinct ‘inspection’ duty, its reference to dangers the owner “should reasonably have been aware” of is consistent with a duty to use reasonable care to inspect, discover, and remedy hazards and to warn invitees of non-obvious dangers. Thus it supports the general proposition about the scope of the duty to invitees.
Polak v. Whitney, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 349,.relevant_excerpt: McDonald, as the owner of the premises to which Polak was invited, had a duty to exercise reasonable care for his safety. … This duty included an obligation on McDonald’s part to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn her guests of any unreasonable dangers of which she was aware or should reasonably have been aware. It was a duty which did not end abruptly at the boundary line of the property over which she exercised control.

Johnson v. Warrington, 2012 Mass. App. D.raw_text: Johnson v. Warrington, 2012 Mass. App. Div. 219, 220–21.
Johnson v. Warrington, 2012 Mass. App. D.proposition: This duty includes the obligation to use reasonable care to (a) inspect for dangerous conditions; (b) discover and remedy hazards on the premises; and (c) warn invitees of dangers which the owner knows or reasonably should know about and which invitees are unlikely to discover on their own.
Johnson v. Warrington, 2012 Mass. App. D.support_reasoning: The Johnson v. Warrington excerpt concerns a landlord-tenant dispute over lease renewal, breach, and appellate procedure, not premises liability or a landowner’s duty of care to invitees. It does not discuss duties to inspect, discover, remedy, or warn of dangerous conditions. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the stated premises liability proposition.
Johnson v. Warrington, 2012 Mass. App. D.relevant_excerpt: In May, 2010, plaintiff Stephen Aldrich ("Aldrich") leased to defendant Heather Silverberg ("Silverberg") residential premises in Arlington, Massachusetts... The lease was for a ten-month or "academic year" term... The lease provided that if Silverberg failed to move out by June 15, 2011, a penalty rent of $5,000.00 would be assessed... [The opinion then addresses renewal of the lease, alleged breach, and procedural issues on appeal.]

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973).
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: A business proprietor such as Defendant has a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep aisles, passageways, and floors of its store reasonably safe for customers, and to take reasonable steps to remedy or warn of spills and slippery substances on the floor.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states the obligation of one who controls business premises to use due care to keep the premises reasonably safe for patrons and to warn of dangers the possessor knows or should know of. It then applies that duty in the specific context of foreign substances on floors or stairways, including the need to discover and remove such substances when they have been present long enough. That directly matches the proposition about a proprietor’s duty to keep aisles and floors reasonably safe and to remedy or warn of spills and slippery substances.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know. … Where a foreign substance on a floor or stairway causes the business visitor to fall and sustain injuries, he may prove the negligence of the defendant…”

Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.raw_text: Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass. 560, 562–63 (1955).
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.proposition: A business proprietor such as Defendant has a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep aisles, passageways, and floors of its store reasonably safe for customers, and to take reasonable steps to remedy or warn of spills and slippery substances on the floor.
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion directly states the duty of a store owner to keep premises reasonably safe for customers and explains that, when a dangerous condition arises from third-party acts, the proprietor must have a reasonable opportunity to learn of and remedy it. The court applies this standard to a spill (melted ice cream), analyzing whether the defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered and removed the slippery substance. This aligns closely with the proposition about a business proprietor’s duty regarding spills and slippery substances on floors and aisles.
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We said in White v. Mugar, 280 Mass. 73, at page 75, ‘The defendant owed to customers a duty to keep the premises reasonably safe for their use. He, however, is not an insurer of safety. Where, without action for which he is responsible, a dangerous condition arises, the law allows him reasonable opportunity to become informed of the danger and to take measures to remedy it. He is not liable, in such a case, unless he is negligent in failing to inform himself and to take appropriate action.’ … The plaintiff’s right to recover therefore depends upon evidence from which the jury could find that the defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of and removed this foreign substance.”

Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.raw_text: Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263, 264–65 (1961).
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.proposition: Alternatively, Defendant had constructive knowledge of the Spill because, based on the visible cart tracks and the location of the employee in close proximity to the Spill, the Spill existed for a sufficient length of time that, in the exercise of reasonable care, Defendant should have discovered and remedied it.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.support_reasoning: The case addresses constructive notice but holds that the evidence (including the employee’s proximity and visibility and the condition/extent of the spill) was insufficient to show the spill existed long enough to be discovered in the exercise of reasonable care. The court explicitly finds no evidence that the oil had been on the floor for a sufficient length of time or that the nearby employee should have seen it. Thus, this opinion rejects, rather than supports, the proposition that such facts establish constructive knowledge.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.relevant_excerpt: “In this state of the case it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence… The record discloses no description of the appearance of the oil which would in any way suggest that it had been on the floor for a sufficient length of time to have been discovered… With regard to the opportunity for discovery, while it was ‘possible’ for the nearest employee… to have seen the spot… there was no evidence that the ‘blotch’ of oil was in his direct line of vision or within his plain view….”

Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.raw_text: Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Mass. 273, 274–76 (1911).
Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.proposition: Alternatively, Defendant had constructive knowledge of the Spill because, based on the visible cart tracks and the location of the employee in close proximity to the Spill, the Spill existed for a sufficient length of time that, in the exercise of reasonable care, Defendant should have discovered and remedied it.
Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.case_name: Anjou v. Boston Elevated Railway Co.
Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses constructive notice in a slip-and-fall context, holding that the condition and appearance of the banana peel permitted an inference it had been on the platform a considerable time and would have been discovered and removed had employees used reasonable care. This aligns with the proposition that, from visible indicia (here, the peel’s dirty, trampled, flattened state) and employee presence, a jury can find the hazard existed long enough that the defendant should have discovered and remedied it.
Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The inference might have been drawn from the appearance and condition of the banana peel that it had been upon the platform a considerable period of time, in such position that it would have been seen and removed by the employees of the defendant if they had performed their duty. Therefore, there is something on which to base a conclusion that it was not dropped a moment before by a passenger… Hence there was evidence of negligence on the part of the defendant, which should have been submitted to the jury.”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a plaintiff in a negligence action must show the existence of a duty, breach of that duty, causation, and damages.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the elements a plaintiff must prove to prevail on a negligence claim in Massachusetts: duty, breach, damages, and a causal relationship between breach and damage. This is expressed as a general statement of negligence law, not limited to the specific firearm-storage context, so it directly supports the cited proposition.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).relevant_excerpt: "To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage."  Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a plaintiff in a negligence action must show the existence of a duty, breach of that duty, causation, and damages.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the elements the plaintiffs must prove in a negligence action: breach of a duty to use reasonable care, actual loss (damages), and causation, and it proceeds on the assumption that a duty must exist. Although the passage focuses on breach, causation, and damages, the structure of the discussion and the reliance on standard tort authorities reflects the Massachusetts formulation that negligence requires duty, breach, causation, and damages.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.relevant_excerpt: With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 783–84 (2007).
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Defendant’s failure to address the Spill for “a few minutes” after its employee first noticed it, while continuing to allow customers to walk through the dairy aisle without warning, constituted a breach of Defendant’s duty of reasonable care under the circumstances.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion adopts the mode-of-operation approach and holds that summary judgment was improper because the store had notice of inherent risks from its self-service operation. It does not address, factually or legally, any scenario where an employee actually observed a specific spill and then failed for “a few minutes” to address it while allowing customers to pass. The case speaks in general terms about foreseeability and reasonable precautions but does not establish that a brief delay after actual notice of a specific spill is, by itself, a breach of duty.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “Additionally, a store owner will be liable to a plaintiff injured as a result of a dangerous condition caused by a third party only if the owner could reasonably foresee that the dangerous condition could occur, resulting from the owner’s chosen mode of operation, and the owner took inadequate steps to forestall resulting injuries.… [T]he trier of fact must determine whether the owner could reasonably foresee or anticipate that the dangerous condition regularly occurs and whether the owner took all necessary reasonable precautions….”

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.proposition: Defendant reasonably should have anticipated that customers, including Plaintiff, would not recognize the specific danger posed by the Spill in time to protect themselves, and that without timely cleanup or adequate warning, customers would encounter the hazard.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.support_reasoning: The case does address when a landowner must anticipate that lawful entrants will encounter an open and obvious hazard, but the core principle it adopts is that the landowner can and should anticipate harm *even though* the danger is known or obvious and may be deliberately encountered. It does not stand for a rule that customers (or lawful entrants) will ‘not recognize the specific danger’ in time; instead, it assumes the danger is recognized/obvious and focuses on foreseeability that people will nevertheless choose to encounter it. Thus it does not support a proposition premised on plaintiffs’ failure to recognize the danger.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.relevant_excerpt: “A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’… Section 343A thus instructs that although a duty to warn of an open and obvious danger would be superfluous … a landowner is not relieved from remedying that danger where he knows or has reason to know that lawful entrants may not heed the warning for a variety of reasons, including their own failure to exercise reasonable care.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85 (comparative negl.proposition: To the extent any comparative negligence is claimed by Defendant, Plaintiff denies such allegations and asserts that any negligence on Defendant’s part was the primary and substantial cause of her injuries.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B..proposition: Plaintiff additionally seeks statutory prejudgment interest on any judgment entered in her favor, as provided by G.L. c. 231, § 6B.

Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401,.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to her medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and other consequential damages.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401,.support_reasoning: The case is about whether a social host owes a duty in negligence to third parties injured by an intoxicated guest and holds that no such duty exists when the host neither serves nor provides alcohol. It does not discuss the measure or categories of damages recoverable once negligence is established, such as medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, or consequential damages. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition concerning the scope of damages recoverable for negligence.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401,.relevant_excerpt: "Any liability on the defendant's part in such a situation must be grounded in the common law of negligence... meaning that the plaintiff has the burden of proving each and every element of that claim: duty, breach of duty (or, the element of negligence), causation (actual and proximate) and damages."
